speaker: Doctor
text: What specific feeding difficulties are you noticing? Is he refusing to eat, or is he having trouble swallowing?

speaker: Patient
text: He's been fussing a lot during feedings and seems to lose interest quickly. Sometimes he just cries instead of eating.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has he been experiencing any vomiting or regurgitation after feedings?

speaker: Patient
text: No, he hasn't been vomiting or regurgitating at all. It's just that he cries a lot during and after feedings.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has he been having any bowel movements? If so, how often and what do they look like?

speaker: Patient
text: He has been having bowel movements, but they seem less frequent than usual. They look normal in consistency, but I'm not sure if that's typical for him.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has there been any noticeable change in his weight or growth patterns recently?

speaker: Patient
text: He seems to be gaining weight despite the feeding difficulties, but I'm not sure if that's normal for him. His mother thinks he might be growing, but it's hard to tell.

speaker: Doctor
text: Has he been experiencing any abdominal pain or discomfort, such as crying or fussing when you touch his belly?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, he cries intensely when I touch his belly, and he seems really uncomfortable. It's been hard to soothe him during those times.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in the color or consistency of his stool, such as blood or mucus?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't seen any blood or mucus in his stool. It looks normal in consistency, just less frequent than usual.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any signs of dehydration, such as dry mouth, decreased urine output, or lethargy?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any signs of dehydration. His mouth seems moist, and he still has wet diapers, so I think he's okay in that regard. He does seem a bit more tired than usual, though.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you observed any abdominal swelling or distension, and if so, how pronounced is it?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, his abdomen does seem distended. It feels quite firm to the touch, and it's noticeable when I look at him.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in his appetite or any specific foods that he seems to prefer or reject?

speaker: Patient
text: He doesn't seem to have a preference for any specific foods; he just loses interest quickly. It's like he doesn't want to eat at all, no matter what I offer him.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any unusual behaviors, such as excessive crying, irritability, or lethargy outside of feeding times?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, he has been more irritable than usual, and he seems to be crying a lot, even when he's not feeding. He also appears a bit more tired and less active than he typically is.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any signs of a fever or any recent illnesses that could be related to his current condition?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any signs of fever or any recent illnesses. He hasn't been sick since birth, so this is all quite unusual for him.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in his skin color, such as paleness or jaundice?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in his skin color. He looks normal to me, no signs of paleness or jaundice.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you observed any unusual swelling in his legs or feet, or any signs of fluid retention?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any swelling in his legs or feet, and there don't seem to be any signs of fluid retention. His legs look normal to me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any unusual sounds coming from his abdomen, such as gurgling or high-pitched noises?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't really noticed any unusual sounds coming from his abdomen. It mostly just seems distended and firm when I touch it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in his sleep patterns, such as difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep?

speaker: Patient
text: He has been having a harder time falling asleep and seems to wake up more often during the night. He appears restless and uncomfortable while sleeping.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any specific triggers that seem to worsen his discomfort or feeding difficulties, such as certain times of day or activities?

speaker: Patient
text: It seems to get worse in the late afternoon and evening. He becomes really fussy and cries a lot during those times, especially when it's time to eat.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in his urine output, such as less frequent urination or darker urine?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in his urine output. He still has wet diapers, so I think he's urinating normally.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any signs of reflux, such as arching his back during feedings or unusual posturing?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't seen him arching his back during feedings or anything like that. He mostly just seems uncomfortable and cries a lot instead.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any unusual smells coming from his breath or vomit, even if he hasn't been vomiting?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any unusual smells coming from his breath. It seems normal to me, and he hasn't vomited at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the symptoms you've described, particularly the feeding difficulties, abdominal distension, and irritability, I suspect there may be an underlying issue. I would like to confirm this with a specific test. REQUEST TEST: Abdominal Ultrasound.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: Maximum inferences reached

speaker: Patient
text: I'm still really worried about him. He just seems so uncomfortable and fussy all the time. I wish I could help him feel better.
